fields.description:
When the JIRA server is running on a German box i.e. the Java system properties for language and country are set to "de" and "DE" respectively, but JIRA is set to run in English in the Admin configuration, the Activity Stream plugin still displays in German.

We have to tell the customers to start up JIRA with different Java system properties to fix this issue. It'd be better if the plugin just worked ;)
fields.summary: English translation of Activity Streams plugin does not get used when running JIRA on a German host

fields.description:
In earlier versions of JIRA, localising plugins was more straightforward. These days, it's not clear, for example that the dashboard needs to be translated by adding properties files to various jar files in the bundled plugins zip file.

We could generate a list of all the i18n files during the build and maybe create a readme or something which is referenced by some documentation for localising JIRA.
fields.summary: Need instructions for localising bundled plugins for JIRA 4.0

fields.description:
We have the need to notify a group of users when a critical production issues has been raised. We would like to do this via email and would prefer not to have to create a redundant workflow step to use as the trigger.

We would like to be able to trigger group email notification from Jira based on custom fields or labels.
fields.summary: Improved group notification from Jira

fields.description:
When JIRA 4.0 is stopped and started, the servlet context is torn down and re-run however JIRA has JVM global variables that are still in effect and hence its not really a clean start.

For example lets say a customer gets in the state where the lock file is still in the JIRA home directory.  They will stop JIRA, remove the file and restart JIRA.,

However the global variable that marks that the home directory lock file in in place it still set and hence JIRA wont start.

We need to tear down any global variables on servlet context init and re-evaluate them each time.

Without this fix, we are going to incur extra support costs.
fields.summary: JIRA does not stop and start correctly when the servlet context is pulled down.  Makes supportting JIRA harder

fields.description:
I created a filter to view issues watched by me, voted by me or unresolved and reported by me. It returned over 500 issues. When trying to set filter column order, the screen has no horizontal scrollbar, as shown.

Seemed to work OK on Firefox.
fields.summary: No horizontal scrollbar when editing filter

fields.description: See screenshot, the bottom part of the phrase "Remember my login" is cut off, so the y and g are not fully visible.
fields.summary: Bottom pixels of phrase cut off in login gadget

fields.description:

Unless it's just something weird at my workstation?? Can you reproduce?

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19517].
  {panel}

Let's say you are an administrator and you want to edit a project's permission screen. And it's been a while since you've done this.

First you go to Projects and select the project you want. Oh wait. No administration functions here.

Then you go to the Administration tab, then select Project. It pops up a list of projects. Great! There are 3 choices, "View Edit Delete". You pick "Edit" since you are changing something. Oh wait, it's just the main project metadata (name, picture, etc). This is confusing.

Finally you go back and you pick "View". This shows all the project details besides the main project metadata. Here's where you can actually edit the major settings of a project, not on the "Edit" page but on the "View" page.

=====

Some suggestions for improved usability.

1) Get rid of the separate "View" "Edit" "Delete" screens and the "Operations" column on the "Administration" page. Combine them together. All 3 of them allow administrators to modify a project. It's too confusing to remember when I have to use "View" to edit a project setting, and when I have to use "Edit" to edit a project setting.

2) For "Delete", have a button or link that says Delete Project, but add a note below the button or link that says "(You will be asked to confirm)" or something. It's disconcerting to see "Delete" and think "Wait... if I'm not 100% sure, will clicking this immediately wipe the project away forever?"

3) On the regular Projects tab, when you select a project, add an "Administration" tab for administrators, so that you can modify the project settings from here, and are not forced to go to the Administration->Projects page.
fields.summary: Simplify project administration through more consistent/uniform access to project administration

fields.description:
This is a request from one of our other users. Basically the idea is to allow a user to see issues for which there is new information he hasn't seen yet.

It is easy to get swamped by the number of issues. It would be helpful if the server would be configured to keep track of whether a user has read an issue or comment. This way it would be possible to search for "issues I have not read yet", much like is possible on most bulletin board forum software. (and if there's a new comment, reset the flag for that user-issue pair.)

The email notification feature allows the server to avoid having to keep track of issue-read state, but this only applies for issues that a user receives notification for.

Yes, this would require at least M*N bits, where M = # of users, N = number of issues, so maybe it's unfeasible for large issue databases, but even for modest databases where, say, M=100, N=10000 you are still talking only 10^6 bits of storage.
fields.summary: read flag for issues / comments

fields.description:
On our JIRA instance, running a JQL query of "issue in watchedIssues()" takes about a minute to complete.  FYI, our watchers table has 814,000 rows.

To work around this we are still using the Voters and Watchers custom field plugin.
fields.summary: watchedIssues() JQL function is very slow

fields.description: There are other issues tracking the work that's being done in fixing the problems with Weblogic 10.  This request is specifically to add Weblogic 10 to the list of [supported application servers for JIRA|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Supported+Application+Servers#SupportedApplicationServers-WebLogic] once it's fixed and tested.
fields.summary: Add support for Weblogic 10
JIRA ships with a duplicate xerces jar (ofbcore-xerces-serialize.jar) that can cause problems with OSGi dependencies.

Hello,

When trying to create a project with a custom avatar you can get the following exception:

{noformat}
2009-10-23 14:34:52,727 http-8090-Processor21 ERROR admin 52472x387x1 avxhi0 /secure/admin/AddProject.jspa [500ErrorPage.jsp] Exception caught in 500 page You can not update a project with an invalid validation result.
java.lang.IllegalStateException: You can not update a project with an invalid validation result.
	at com.atlassian.jira.bc.project.DefaultProjectService.updateProject(DefaultProjectService.java:212)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.project.AddProject.doExecute(AddProject.java:93)
	at webwork.action.ActionSupport.execute(ActionSupport.java:153)
	at com.atlassian.jira.action.JiraActionSupport.execute(JiraActionSupport.java:59)
	at webwork.dispatcher.GenericDispatcher.executeAction(GenericDispatcher.java:141)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.dispatcher.JiraServletDispatcher.service(JiraServletDispatcher.java:181)
	at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:729)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:269)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:188)
	at com.atlassian.core.filters.HeaderSanitisingFilter.doFilter(HeaderSanitisingFilter.java:44)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:215)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:188)
{noformat}

This happens when a user tries to create a project they don't actually have permission to browse. For example, you can simply remove the 'jira-users' group from the default project role configuration (as I have done in the attached configuration).

*Work Around*: Simply give the admin user browse permission to the project.

The project actually gets created, it just that the avatar cannot be changed.

I would assume that an administrator of the project would be able to change the project avatar during creation. I would also assume that the avatar could be changed after, but this also does not appear to be possible. There are some other operations that also don't seem to work unless you have browse permission.
fields.summary: Can't create project with "Custom Avatar" when the project creator does not have browse permission.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19511].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 19 Jan 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your feedback is key to helping us understand how you use JIRA so we can continue improving your experience. We have reviewed this issue over the last few days.

Speed and performance are a priority for us. While there is still room for improvement when it comes to load times of the Dashboard, we believe at this point we have made sufficient progress to close this request. We continue investment in performance and more improvements are on ther way.

There was significant effort put into transformation of Gadgets to Dashboard Items. There are still some Gadgets pending transformation. The Activity Stream gadget being the heaviest, and it is scheduled for transformation within next 6 months. We expect further high impact on Dashboard performance from this. We also made some improvements in the front-end by removing DCL handlers.

In JIRA Cloud instances, Dashboard loading time still sometimes suffers from the fact that for ~25% of user sessions it is the first page after login, and therefore it's affected by cold caches and resources download. The solution here is not to improve the Dashboard anymore but to fix cold caches and resource delivery. We’re working on it.

To benefit from the above mentioned improvements we recommend for JIRA Server customers to upgrade to at least JIRA 6.4. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.

Regards,
Daniel Franz
dfranz at atlassian dot com
Principal Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}
  

Dashboard is taking way more time to load than previous version. Everyone noticed it here and it is a major downgrade from 3.13.

On our local network, the dashboard is noticeably slower. From outside on SSL connection, it is annoying.

It seems like there is an load of HTTP requests made each time dashboard is load. Could'nt gadget be sent with the main page instead of being loaded after?
fields.summary: Excessive Dashboard loading time
Add parameter to email handlers not to add new users to the "JIRA Users" global permisisons

fields.description:
Hey guys,

Just trying to knock up a very simple plugin that adds to the JIRA 4
nav bar and found some holes in the docs:

1) we don't link to the web fragments page (which shows the _keys_ of
JIRA's web items / sections) from the web item/section pages! (I took
a while to find it - and had to ask Nick M)

eg http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Web+Section+Plugin+Module
should definitely link to
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Web+Fragments

2) The locations listed in the Web Fragments doc are out of date, as
are the screenshots (which are linked when you click on a section - to
indicate where to link to).

3) We need to explain to people how to add menu items and specifically
_drop down menus_ for JIRA 4 - this is not in the docs anywhere, and
is a very useful feature that I assume plugin authors will want to
write.

Hope this all makes sense - feel free to sing out if it doesn't!

m
fields.summary: update Web Fragments and Web Items developer docs

fields.summary: Menu items with no dropdowns are misaligned

fields.description:
Jira should save a change history for versions, the same way it does for issues.


One of the great features in Jira is the ability to generate statistics.  

One of the most important development statistic is delivery slippage.  I have no way to track when a version release date has been changed.  Also, the release notes take a snapshot of the current issue list, not a comparative list to the original planning.  There should be a baseline function for version planning.  

Do such capabilities exist in greenhopper?
fields.summary: Version History should be recorded.

fields.description:
When adding a Two Dimensional Filter Statistics Portlet, the 'Save' button is missing from that portlet. Please see attached screenshot.

The root cause was the user without having any saved filters tied to his/her account.

This bug could be solved when you create and save at least any one filter. The 'Save' button will then be shown.
fields.summary: Missing 'Save' Button in Two Dimensional Filter Statistics Portlet

fields.description:
Server is set in public mode.  The configuration option for email is set to hidden.
The XMLRPC interface is enabled for authenticated users.

It is trivial to find a users email.

Concept python code follows:

#!/usr/bin/python

import xmlrpclib
import sys

s = xmlrpclib.ServerProxy('http://*myhostname.fqdn*/rpc/xmlrpc')
auth = s.jira1.login('*username*', '*password*')

user = s.jira1.getUser(auth, sys.argv[1])
print "Email address of " + sys.argv[1] + " is " + user['email']
fields.summary: XMLRPC information security leak

fields.description:
A customer reported that his setup with [SQL Server 2008|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Connecting+JIRA+to+SQL+Server+2008] failed due to database case-sensitivity.

He believes that the SQL Server 2008 documentation fail to mention this - setting database case sensitivity allowed him to proceed with the installation.

The [SQL Server 2005 installation guide|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Setting+up+your+JIRA+database+for+MS+SQL+Server+2005] mentioned that the database has to be case-insensitive. Please have this information in the SQL Server 2008 doc too.
fields.summary: Update SQL Server 2008 documentation for JIRA

fields.description:
Implement something that would track how likely a given release date is by looking historically to predict the accuracy of the estimation.

JIRA has the data:

    * Past accuracy estimates for each project / component / developer
    * Estimates of un-resolved issues
    * Release dates
    * GreenHopper adds the ability to track holidays in the given timeframe
    * Etc.

A chart or table showing the liklihood of hitting the release date is ___%.
fields.summary: Evidence Based Scheduling Feature

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Trying to import data into JIRA that contains a custom field with no name (i.e. "") fails with an exception.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Create an XML backup, and remove the name of a custom field.
# Attempt to import it.

h3. Expected Results

# The importer provides an error about the data.

h3. Actual Results

The below exception is thrown:

{noformat}
com.atlassian.jira.util.dbc.Assertions$BlankStringArgumentException: names[0] should not be empty!
        at com.atlassian.jira.util.dbc.Assertions.containsNoBlanks(Assertions.java:112)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.ClauseNames.<init>(ClauseNames.java:42)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.ClauseNames.<init>(ClauseNames.java:36)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.ClauseNames.forCustomField(ClauseNames.java:71)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.CustomFieldImpl.getClauseNames(CustomFieldImpl.java:281)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.customfields.searchers.TextSearcher.init(TextSearcher.java:62)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.customfields.searchers.TextSearcher.init(TextSearcher.java:33)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.CustomFieldImpl.getCustomFieldSearcher(CustomFieldImpl.java:1502)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.CustomFieldImpl.createAssociatedSearchHandler(CustomFieldImpl.java:615)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.managers.DefaultSearchHandlerManager$SearchHandlerIndexer.indexSearchableField(DefaultSearchHandlerManager.java:448)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.managers.DefaultSearchHandlerManager$SearchHandlerIndexer.indexCustomField(DefaultSearchHandlerManager.java:435)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.managers.DefaultSearchHandlerManager.getHelper(DefaultSearchHandlerManager.java:235)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.managers.DefaultSearchHandlerManager.getAllSearchers(DefaultSearchHandlerManager.java:202)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.managers.DefaultIssueSearcherManager.getAllSearchers(DefaultIssueSearcherManager.java:27)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.managers.FieldIndexerManagerImpl.init(FieldIndexerManagerImpl.java:68)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.managers.FieldIndexerManagerImpl.<init>(FieldIndexerManagerImpl.java:51)
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

Perform the workaround in the instance that has the problematic data in it.

# Identify the problem record with the below SQL:
{code:SQL}
select * from customfield where cfname is null or cfname = '';
{code}
# Backup the JIRA instance.
# Stop JIRA.
# Update the field with the below:
{code:SQL}
update customfield set cfname = '<give me a name>' where id = <id from step 1>;
{code}
# Start JIRA.
# Attempt a reindex.

If this proceeds, the data can be exported and then imported into the target instance.
fields.summary: An Empty Custom Field Name causes JIRA 4.0 not to start correctly.

fields.description:
I deployed JIRA 4.0 to weblogic 9.2 and noticed that the steps in our documentation are not accurate. I think it is the documentation for 8.x.

The main things that are wrong are:

# Classpath variable to add the database library is WEBLOGIC_CLASSPATH
# database configuration: The exact steps have changed from 8.x to 9.2 and I think we should not go into too much detail about how exactly you create the datasource. The audience who is reading our guide should be familiar with Weblogic and we should only supply JIRA specific configuration that has to be done.
# creating a jira server: Creating a server is actually a bit more complex and requires also to configure other areas (e.g. a server has to be associated with a 'machine'). But if we agree on only providing jira specific configuration required for weblogic, this step can stay.

I think it will require around two days to update these steps for 9.2.
fields.summary: Documentation for Installing JIRA 4.0 on Oracle WebLogic 9.2 is not accurate

fields.description:
Currently, the user properties are associated to the User IDs, not the user names.

If an external User repository is integrated with JIRA (ie. Crowd), on the first login, the user will be added to the *external_entities* table and it will receive a brand new ID. This ID will be different from the one being used in the user Personal Settings (propertyentry table), causing the users to loose the references to the data.

The *propertyentry* table also differentiates OSUser and External_entities entries using the *ENTITY_NAME* field. So, not only the ID will be different, but the ENTITY_NAME as well.

Since this use case is very common (Users were being stored in JIRA DB and then the customer decides to start using Crowd), there should be an automatic way to associate the old Personal Settings to the user in the new repository.
fields.summary: Add migration of User Personal settings when JIRA is integrated with an external User Repository (ie. Crowd)

fields.description:
After purchasing JIRA, I was very disappointed to have to go through a bunch of configuration and troubleshooting and reading of scattered documentation to get JIRA setup for production use with IIS and Microsoft SQL Server. The default installation is not usable in production environments. JIRA installs on an atypical port (8080) and uses a non-production in-memory database. To setup JIRA on a publicly available URL (http://support.mycompany.com/jira) using a production database (Microsoft SQL Server), I had to endure two entirely different (IIS and MS SQL Server) and insufficiently documented series of manual steps that involved downloading third-party components (jtds, isapi_redirect), carefully manipulating a variety of configuration files scattered across a variety of configuration directories, setting permissions in Windows and IIS and MS SQL Server, adding web filters and web extensions, troubleshooting common errors, and so on. Once the steps had been figured out, it was clear that they could be automated with just a few prompts.

I realize that other customers use Java app servers, Oracle, Linux, etc. But you should fully automate the installation of the most common configurations. If IIS/MSSQL is not common, then I can live with that, but I'm guessing that the vast majority of your customers are running (or would like to be running) on one of 3 or 4 common configurations.
fields.summary: Automate the installation of common production configuration(s) in Windows environment

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19479].
  {panel}

I installed JIRA on a hosted Windows server that was running IIS and other web sites on port 80. I needed to expose JIRA on a port that was open to the firewall (i.e. port 80) and using a URL that customers would find friendly, such as http://support.mycompany.com/jira. I walked through these two docs:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+IIS+with+Tomcat
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Integrating+JIRA+with+IIS

but I still had several major issues that prevented the site from working. Please add these steps and troubleshooting items to your IIS integration docs:

A) Grant Windows ACL permissions to the c:\tomcat_iis_connector folder. Right-click the folder, go to the Security tab, ensure that you grant Full permissions for the IIS_WPG group (or the Identity used by the Application Pool if it does not belong to the IIS_WPG group). Then click the Advanced button and select this option: "Replace permission entries on all child objects with entries shown here that apply to child objects". Click OK.

Troubleshooting: Ensure that you perform step A if you have any of the following problems:
  1) The ISAPI Filters tab shows a red arrow for the isapi_redirect.dll filter added earlier.
  2) You receive a blank response from your custom URL (http://support.mycompany.com/jira)
  3) A log file is not created within the c:\tomcat_iis_connector folder when you restart IIS and access your custom URL.

B) After creating the "jira" virtual directory, grant the Windows ACL Read permission to the Internet Guest Account (typically IUSR_servername) or whatever identity you have selected in your web site Directory Security for anonymous users.

Troubleshooting: If you receive an HTTP 401 (access denied) error from your custom URL (http://support.mycompany.com/jira) then ensure that you have done step B.

Troubleshooting: If JIRA responds on your custom URL (http://support.mycompany.com/jira) you may see the following error for each of the gadgets: "Error loading gadget: org.apache.shindig.gadgets.GadgetException: Unable to retrieve gadget xml. HTTP error 500". This occurs when the JIRA server is unable to resolve the domain name of your custom URL. If your server is hosted or for some other reason cannot resolve support.mycompany.com, then add the following entry to the C:\WINDOWS\SYSTEM32\DRIVERS\ETC\HOSTS file:  127.0.0.1  support.mycompany.com
fields.summary: Things to add to JIRA/IIS integration docs

- Fill in the password
- Click "Log In"

- Safari Version 4.0.3 (6531.9)
- Jira v4.0#466

fields.description: After importing several thousand issues from FogBugz, we noticed that some of the comments that were added to FogBugz via email were missing from the migrated issues.  The Importer reported no errors regarding this.  Since the issues themselves came through ok, along with all comments added via the web interface, it is difficult to say how many email comments didn't import successfully, but a small sample indicates that something in the neighborhood of 50% of email comments failed to import.  We have yet to discern any pattern about which emails imported successfully, and which didn't.  There are even a few issues with multiple comments from the same user, some of which imported successfully, and some of which didn't.
fields.summary: FogBugz Importer doesn't import all comments from emails

fields.description: The CreateOrCommentHandler has a "stripquotes" option that is meant to remove the quoted portion of the text. We have two ways of doing this. One way for Outlook and one way for every other mail client that has ever existed. In the Outlook way we look for the string "---- Begin Original Message ----" to know what to strip. However, it appears that Outlook 2007 only adds this when replying to text email. If you are replying to HTML mail, then Outlook doesn't add that. The result is that the Handler can't stripquotes.
fields.summary: CreateOrCommentHandler doesn't stripquotes from Outlook HTML mail

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19465].
  {panel}

Hello,

while not exactly reproducible (probably an OOM at some stage during the very first installation), JIRA 4 can fail to deploy the bundled plugins successfully and core functionality may be missing from the application.

Subsequent restarts don't detect this condition and JIRA persists in this dysfunctional state until the {{home}} folder is cleared. It would be useful if the startup process verified plugin deployment and automatically repeated the process when necessary.

Possible symptoms of the problems are: missing project settings such as categories, issue type schemes, issue security schemes, field configuration schemes, workflow schemes etc... 

Regards,
Edoardo
fields.summary: JIRA should check on startup for incorrect core plugins deployment

fields.description: We would that all parts of Jira is translated in Italian language.
fields.summary: Completed Italian language translation

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-19463].
  {panel}

At the moment there's one global switch to turn the access to the Remote API on or off.

Sometimes you want finer control. For example, when you've made some customatizations or added some plugins that rely on information on the screens presented to the user. (Either to work correctly or to inform the user correctly). 

In this case you want to have control over who can access the Remote API, and who is forced to use the web interface. In our caser I would like to only grant remote api permission to members of the group 'isaac'.

A global permission would fit the bill nicely. 

You could go even further by making the permission part of the permission schemes to allow per project configuration.
fields.summary: Add Global Permission 'Allow access to remote api'

fields.description:
When looking up the ID for the next workflow step, JIRA does not seem to check that an error has not occurred. If an error has occurred then {{null}} is returned which is subsequently used as a workflow step ID. This causes database integrity errors. 

It would be a good idea if JIRA checked the result of the ID generation before using it. 

Check out the attached file for an example stack trace.
fields.summary: Failure in JIRA Sequence Item lookup can cause cascading errors with JIRA workflow operations.

fields.description:
The WebAttachmentManager allows an attachment to have a PropertySet associated with it.

When you perform a Project Import we do not appear to bring these properties over.
fields.summary: project import drops FileAttachment properties

h3. Cause

If the database records a plugin state for a bundled plugin (i.e. when one is in a non default state) and that state is REMOVE, the BundledPluginLoader will attempt to remove the plugin while it is iterating over the plugins.

h3. Workaround

(i) This workaround relates to a now [End of Life|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/Support/Atlassian+Support+Offerings#AtlassianSupportOfferings-EndofLifePolicy] version of JIRA. If you have any problems with it, please be aware Atlassian will be unable to assist you and it is done so at your own risk.

# Check the plugin states of your current plugins with the below SQL.
{code:SQL}
select * from propertyentry pe left join propertystring ps on pe.id = ps.id where pe.entity_name = 'jira.properties' and pe.property_key like 'jira.plugin.state%'
{code}
# If you see entries with {{REMOVE}} in them, such as the below, these will need correcting.
{noformat}

    </provider>

    </provider>

</opensymphony-user>
{code}
Note _<property name="java.naming.security.credentials">atlassian&8</property>_
# Configure JIRA to use the generated osuser.xml .

JIRA returns the 404 http status and in the log file reports:

2009-10-19 11:01:17,176 main ERROR     [opensymphony.user.util.ConfigLoader] Could not parse config XML
org.xml.sax.SAXParseException: The entity name must immediately follow the '&' in the entity reference.
	at org.apache.xerces.util.ErrorHandlerWrapper.createSAXParseException(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.util.ErrorHandlerWrapper.fatalError(Unknown Source)

fields.description:
The package scanner currently returns the version of the first jar it finds with the given package inside it.
This has two main problems:
* The version number found for a given package is non-deterministic
* If it finds a jar with no version information first, then we have no version information and this can cause errors on startup.
Also, we should include meaningful warnings when multiple versions are found for a given package.

The error message on dependency resolution fail could be made more user-friendly and include extra information needed to resolve the issue.
eg: If we fail to resolve a particular version of a dependency, then we could log all the available versions.
fields.summary: Improve the dependency resolution in OSGi Plugins

fields.description:
On our JIRA 4.0 instance, starting a new Simple search requires only a 1.5 second page load time whereas switching to Advanced mode takes 8 seconds.  This 8 second tax is also present when viewing any search results in the Issue Navigator while in Advanced Search mode.  Looking at the HTML for the Advanced Search page, I see a large div called "jqlFieldz", and I assume it is the generation of this div that is causing the performance slowdown.

For the record I see that j.a.c.'s jqlFieldz div is 18499 bytes long while ours is 122267 bytes long.  Our JIRA instance has 518 custom fields.
fields.summary: Advanced Search dialog is slow to load on an instance with a large number of custom fields

the rendered prefix for the Import Id CF is hardcoded to be looked up from the key {{jira.importid.prefix}} in file {{atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/classes/jira-application.properties}}.

It would be convenient to make this value configurable from the UI so that one could define multiple CF instances with different prefixes and map them to different projects using _field configuration schemes_. Best Regards,
Edoardo

h3. NullPointerException appears in a stack trace when running specific JQL filters in the Issue Navigator

Stack trace is similar to the above

h2. Diagnosis

If you're seeing these exceptions, have a look at the customer data and find out if there are any records in the {{customfieldoption}} table which reference non-existant {{fieldconfiguration}} records. Here is the SQL:

{{select * from customfieldoption where customfieldconfig not in (select id from fieldconfiguration)}}

If there are records returned, then any search which mentions the {{customvalue}} s as the right hand side of a select custom field clause will be affected.

h2. Cause

When deleting a custom field context for a select custom field, the options created are not deleted. They remain in the {{customfieldoption}} table, with references to a {{fieldconfiguration}} (custom field context) that no longer exists (because it was deleted).

A JQL clause that references the option "NAME" will look up all stored custom field options with that name, and attempt to resolve each option to its related field, in order to calculate the context of the clause. This includes all "dead options". When the related custom field is looked up, the NullPointerException is thrown.
fields.summary: NullPointerException when searching using select options that have the same name as previously deleted ones
